#Text=CONTENTS
#Text=PROLOG
#Text=I TOWARD THE ETERNAL FIRES
#Text=II A STRANGE WORLD
#Text=III A CHANGE OF MASTERS
#Text=IV DIAN THE BEAUTIFUL V SLAVES
#Text=VI THE BEGINNING OF HORROR
#Text=VII FREEDOM
#Text=VIII THE MAHAR TEMPLE IX
#Text=THE FACE OF DEATH
#Text=X PHUTRA AGAIN XI
#Text=FOUR DEAD MAHARS
#Text=XII PURSUIT
#Text=XIII THE SLY ONE XIV
#Text=THE GARDEN OF EDEN
#Text=XV BACK TO EARTH
#Text=PROLOG
#Text=IN THE FIRST PLACE PLEASE BEAR IN MIND THAT I do not expect you to believe this story .

#Text=Nor could you wonder had you witnessed a recent experience of mine when , in the armor of blissful and stupendous ignorance , I gaily narrated the gist of it to a Fellow of the Royal Geological Society on the occasion of my last trip to London .

#Text=You would surely have thought that I had been detected in no less a heinous crime than the purloining of the Crown Jewels from the Tower , or putting poison in the coffee of His Majesty the King .
#Text=The erudite gentleman in whom I confided congealed before I was half through ! --
#Text=it is all that saved him from exploding -- and my dreams of an Honorary Fellowship , gold medals , and a niche in the Hall of Fame faded into the thin , cold air of his arctic atmosphere .
#Text=But I believe the story , and so would you , and so would the learned Fellow of the Royal Geological Society , had you and he heard it from the lips of the man who told it to me .
#Text=Had you seen , as I did , the fire of truth in those gray eyes ; had you felt the ring of sincerity in that quiet voice ; had you realized the pathos of it all -- you , too , would believe .
#Text=You would not have needed the final ocular proof that I had -- the weird rhamphorhynchus-like creature which he had brought back with him from the inner world .
#Text=I came upon him quite suddenly , and no less unexpectedly , upon the rim of the great Sahara Desert .
#Text=He was standing before a goat-skin tent amidst a clump of date palms within a tiny oasis .
#Text=Close by was an Arab douar of some eight or ten tents .
#Text=I had come down from the north to hunt lion .
#Text=My party consisted of a dozen children of the desert -- I was the only " white " man .
#Text=As we approached the little clump of verdure I saw the man come from his tent and with hand-shaded eyes peer intently at us .
#Text=At sight of me he advanced rapidly to meet us .
#Text=" A white man ! " he cried .
#Text=" May the good Lord be praised !
#Text=" It cannot be !

#Text=Tell me that you are mistaken , or that you are but joking .

_	_	_	_

#Text= I am telling you the truth , my friend , " I replied .

column1: #Text=" Why should I deceive a stranger , or attempt to , in so simple a matter as the date ? "
#Text=For some time he stood in silence , with bowed head .
#Text=" Ten years ! " he murmured , at last .
#Text=" Ten years , and I thought that at the most it could be scarce more than one ! "
#Text=That night he told me his story -- the story that I give you here as nearly in his own words as I can recall them .
#Text=I
#Text=TOWARD THE ETERNAL FIRES
#Text=I WAS BORN IN CONNECTICUT ABOUT THIRTY YEARS ago .
#Text=My name is David Innes .
#Text=My father was a wealthy mine owner .
#Text=When I was nineteen he died .
#Text=All his property was to be mine when I had attained my majority -- provided that I had devoted the two years intervening in close application to the great business I was to inherit .
#Text=I did my best to fulfil the last wishes of my parent -- not because of the inheritance , but because I loved and honored my father .
#Text=For six months I toiled in the mines and in the counting-rooms , for I wished to know every minute detail of the business .
#Text=Then Perry interested me in his invention .
#Text=He was an old fellow who had devoted the better part of a long life to the perfection of a mechanical subterranean prospector .
#Text=As relaxation he studied paleontology .
#Text=I looked over his plans , listened to his arguments , inspected his working model -- and then , convinced , I advanced the funds necessary to construct a full-sized , practical prospector .
#Text=I shall not go into the details of its construction -- it lies out there in the desert now -- about two miles from here .
#Text=Tomorrow you may care to ride out and see it .
#Text=Roughly , it is a steel cylinder a hundred feet long , and jointed so that it may turn and twist through solid rock if need be .
#Text=At one end is a mighty revolving drill operated by an engine which Perry said generated more power to the cubic inch than any other engine did to the cubic foot .

#Text=I remember that he used to claim that that invention alone would make us fabulously wealthy -- we were going to make the whole thing public after the successful issue of our first secret trial -- but Perry never returned from that trial trip , and I only after ten years .
